Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
06/29/2018. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (ISEP) and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4111 Job description.
An institution shall provide a job description for each staff
position that identifies rules, required qualifications, and lines of
authority.
One out of 30 new employee records reviewed did not contain a job description.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(b) A true copy of verification of education from an accredited
college or university where minimum education requirements
are specified by rule.
One out of 30 applicable new employee records reviewed did not contain a true copy
of verification of education. It is noted that the employee record contained a copy of
verification of education.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian province, or
other country where the person usually resides or has resided in
the previous 5 years.
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state, Canadian provincial, or other
country law enforcement agency where the person usually
resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
4

One out of 30 applicable new employee records reviewed did not contain a record of
convictions from the state the employee resided within the previous five years. The
employee is noted as residing in Texas from 2015 through 2018 though no
clearance from Texas was noted in the record.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
Two out of eight employee records beyond one year of hire did not contain annual
central registry verifications. One record was completed on 03/16/2011 with an
update of 04/05/2018, whereas the other record was last updated on 02/21/2017.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 08/07/2017 INTERIM INSPECTION
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
5

One out of 38 applicable employee records reviewed did not contain a written
evaluation after completion of their probationary period.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 08/07/2017 INTERIM INSPECTION
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
Three out of eight employee records beyond one year of hire did not contain
verification or timely annual verification regarding TB testing. One employee record
contained an x-ray verification dated 04/18/2017, whereas the annual questionnaire
was completed beyond one year on 06/26/2018. The second employee record
contained verification on 01/04/2017 with an annual update on 01/22/2018, 18 days
late. The third employee record did not contain verification of TB being tested.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 08/07/2017 INTERIM INSPECTION
R 400.4116 Chief administrator; responsibilities
(2) An institution’s chief administrator shall be administratively
responsible annually for all of the following functions:
(a) Not less than once annually, conduct a written assessment
and verify the agency’s compliance with these rules.
(b) Develop and implement a written plan to correct, within 6
months, rule violations identified as a result of the assessment
conducted pursuant to subdivision (a) of this subrule.
(c) Conduct a written evaluation of trends and patterns of all
unplanned discharges.
The facility does conduct case file audits to verify compliance with these rules. The
facility did not complete it as specified in Communication Issuance CI 17-018, nor
did the facility use the CWL-4607 Chief Administrator Annual Assessment and
Corrective Action plan form as outlined in CI 17-070.1.

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please

be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
RFCJJ Contract Contractor Responsibilities-Services to be Provided-
Oct 17: 2.10.w – Wardrobe/Personal Possessions
Page 24-25
The Contractor shall assure that each youth has an adequate
wardrobe as defined by and documented on the Clothing
Inventory Checklist (DHHS-337) while in placement and upon
leaving placement. The Contractor shall comply with Mich
Admin Code R 400.4125, JJR Policy JR2 240, Youth Attire and
JR2 260, Youth Property. When the youth is absent or at the
conclusion of the placement, the Contractor shall have a
process in place to return the youth's property to the youth's
parent(s) or legal guardian(s) or keep the youth's wardrobe and
possessions safe until claimed by the youth or MDHHS. If the
possessions are not claimed within 90 calendar days, the
Contractor may dispose of the items at its discretion.
One out of eight applicable case records did not contain a completed clothing
inventory checklist using the DHHS-337. It is noted that the facility utilized its own
clothing inventory checklist, nor was it uploaded into MiSACWIS.

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
RFCJJ Contract Contractor Responsibilities-Services to be Provided-
Oct 17: 2.10.y.2) Related Services-Psychiatric Services-Psychotropic
Page 26 & JR3 Medication–Informed Consent DHHS-1643
340 page 4-5
Informed consent must be obtained for administration to a youth
of each psychotropic medication. The Contractor shall follow
JR3 340, Psychotropic Medications and document the informed
consent process in MiSACWIS.
8

In one applicable case record reviewed medication consents were obtained and are
in the hard copy file. The medication consents have not been uploaded into
MiSACWIS and is the responsibility of the DHHS Psychotropic Medication Oversight
Unit (PMOU), per CI 17-164 for foster care and dual wards. Best practice is to
include verification in the case record that medication consents have been forwarded
to the DHHS worker and PMOU for dual wards.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(b) A photograph taken within the previous 12 months.
The facility updates resident’s pictures annually. Best practice is to date the annual
pictures.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted five acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The facility submitted a corrective action plan for the 08/07/2017 interim inspection. It
successfully addressed the following citations as no repeat citations are currently
noted: Documentation of legal right to provide care, and discharge information
regarding ongoing services. Repeat citations include: Timely completion of annual
staff central registries and TB tests, and completion of staff performance evaluations.
9

SIR2018C0219030 initiated on 03/21/2018 cited the facility for staff supervision
regarding resident acquiring marijuana. The CAP included security personnel being
retrained in visitation and search procedures, and staff supervision.
SIR2018C0219032 initiated on 03/26/2018 cited the facility for primary restraint
technique implementation. The CAP included retraining in restraint techniques for the
staff person involved.
SIR2018C0219034 initiated on 03/28/2018 cited the facility for restraint not being
required and technique, as well appropriate use of seclusion. The CAP included
retraining with the restraint philosophy and intervention techniques, training in trauma
and seclusion, as well as staff suspension.
SIR2018C0219048 initiated on 05/16/2018 cited the facility in regards to staff not
utilizing verbal de-escalation before placing resident in restraint. The CAP included
retraining with the restraint philosophy and trauma, as well as staff suspension.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
